fields.Title of Contribution: The population interplay of two malaria vectors in northeastern Uganda and their measured declines with vector control
fields.Description/Abstract:
Background:
Indoor residual spraying (IRS) is widely regarded as a desirable, highly
suppressive malaria control intervention. In a perennially high-transmission
setting of northeastern Uganda, the effects of multiple rounds of a high-coverage
IRS program with pirimiphos-methyl (Actellic) were measured and assessed.
Monthly mosquito collections were amassed via CDC light traps placed at 90
randomly-selected sentinel households throughout a rural area of ∼175km2with
∼50,000 residents, the study site of malaria transmission and its control.
Methods:
Of three subcounties investigated two received IRS with pirimiphos methyl, and
mosquitoes in these areas, with and without these interventions, are collected for
a single night at monthly intervals for nearly three years. Seasonal and locational
trends of these collections are reported and compared, notably those of the two
primary malarial vectors of the area, the An. gambiae s.l. and An. funestus.
These collections are also tested for sporozoite positivity with enzyme-linked
immunosorbent assays (ELISA).
Results:
In the absence of vector control, mosquito densities are found to rise and fall
with the biannual rains of the region, but the primary (March-June) rainfall
prompts high An gambiae s.l. densities while the secondary (September-October)
wet season is associated with high An. funestus collections. These
seasonally-coordinated, sequential density peaks, each dominated by a single
species are observed over all years and regions of the study. Sporozoite positivity
determined from ELISA testing indicates that malaria transmission in the region
takes place throughout the year but also alternates between the vectors,
coordinated with these seasons and species. A spatially complex picture of these
mosquito densities is also observed with the two species found to frequently share
the same locales but not at the same times of the year, consistent with a
sympatric, but not syntopic interspecific interaction. The measured impacts of
high-coverage IRS are also very apparent on the mosquito collections, with
percentage reductions generally 60-80% compared to the neighboring subcounty
without, and An. funestus collections are found to be modestly more impacted by
the campaigns than the An. gambiae complex in all cases.
Conclusions:
These vector control efforts in Katakwi have been effective in suppressing the
two primary anopheline vectors with seasonally distinct density peaks. In such a
high transmission setting with multiple vectors, they should be seasonally
performed and a bespoke strategy of observation combined with species-specific
control is merited.
